name: Prithvi Narayan Shah
title: Founder of Modern Nepal, First King of Unified Nepal
info: Known as the founder of modern Nepal, Prithvi Narayan Shah was the last king of the Gorkha Kingdom and the first monarch of the unified Kingdom of Nepal. He unified the three Malla kingdoms of Kathmandu, Patan, and Bhaktapur in 1769. He was born to King Nara Bhupal Shah and Queen Kaushalyavati. He is famous for his military campaigns and the unification of Nepal, calling it a 'garden of four castes and thirty-six sub-castes'. He established the foundation of the modern Nepalese state through his conquest campaigns.

name: Pratap Singh Shah
title: Second King of Nepal
info: Pratap Singh Shah was the second king of the Shah dynasty. He ascended the throne at the age of 23 after his father's death. His reign was relatively short, lasting only about 2 years and 10 months. He died prematurely, and his death led to a regency period as his son Rana Bahadur was only 2 years old. His wife, Queen Rajendra Rajya Lakshmi Devi, became regent after his death. He had conflicts with his brother Bahadur Shah over succession and power.

name: Rana Bahadur Shah
title: Third King of Nepal
info: Rana Bahadur Shah became king at the age of 2 following his father's death. He ruled under the regency of his mother Queen Rajendra Rajya Lakshmi Devi (until 1785) and later his uncle Bahadur Shah. During his reign, Nepal expanded its territory through conquest, including the Garhwal and Kumaon regions. He imprisoned his uncle Bahadur Shah, who died in jail. In 1799, he abdicated the throne in favor of his son Girvan Yuddha Bikram Shah and became a Buddhist monk. He was assassinated in 1806 by his half-brother Sher Bahadur Shah.

name: Girvan Yuddha Bikram Shah
title: Fourth King of Nepal
info: Girvan Yuddha Bikram Shah became king at the age of 1 year and 5 months when his father Rana Bahadur Shah abdicated. His reign was marked by the Anglo-Nepalese War (1814-1816) which resulted in Nepal losing significant territory including areas in the Terai and hills. The war ended with the Treaty of Sugauli in 1816, which reduced Nepal to about two-thirds of its territory. He died of smallpox at the young age of 19. His reign was largely controlled by regents due to his young age.

name: Rajendra Bikram Shah
title: Fifth King of Nepal
info: Rajendra Bikram Shah became king at the age of 3 under the regency of his step-grandmother Queen Lalita Tripura Sundari Devi and Prime Minister Bhimsen Thapa. His reign saw the rise of the Rana dynasty's power. The Kot Massacre of 1846 marked the beginning of Rana rule, after which Jung Bahadur Rana became the de facto ruler of Nepal. In 1847, he was imprisoned by Jung Bahadur Rana and forced to abdicate in favor of his son Surendra Bikram Shah. He spent his remaining years in virtual house arrest.

name: Surendra Bikram Shah
title: Sixth King of Nepal
info: Surendra Bikram Shah became king at the age of 17 when his father was forced to abdicate. However, his reign was largely ceremonial as the Rana dynasty held actual power. He was essentially a figurehead king with limited authority. During his reign, the Rana system of hereditary prime ministership was consolidated. His eldest son, Crown Prince Trailokya, died in 1878, three years before Surendra's own death. His reign lasted 34 years, though he had very little real power during this period.

name: Prithvi Bir Bikram Shah
title: Seventh King of Nepal
info: Prithvi Bir Bikram Shah was the grandson of Surendra Bikram Shah and became king at the age of 5 following his grandfather's death. Like his predecessor, he was a figurehead king under the Rana regime. His reign was entirely controlled by the Rana prime ministers. He died prematurely at the age of 36, and his young son Tribhuvan succeeded him. His reign of 30 years was marked by continued Rana dominance and the king's lack of real political power.
father: Crown Prince Trailokya Bir Bikram Shah

name: Tribhuvan Bir Bikram Shah
title: Eighth King of Nepal
info: Tribhuvan Bir Bikram Shah became king at the age of 5 following his father's death. He is known for his role in ending the Rana regime. In 1950, he fled to the Indian Embassy in Kathmandu seeking asylum, which led to the end of Rana rule. After negotiations, he was restored to the throne in 1951 with actual powers. He played a crucial role in the democratic movement and the establishment of a constitutional monarchy. He died in Switzerland while undergoing medical treatment. His reign marked the transition from Rana autocracy to constitutional monarchy.

name: Mahendra Bir Bikram Shah
title: Ninth King of Nepal
info: Mahendra Bir Bikram Shah became king following his father's death. He is known for establishing the Panchayat system in 1960, which was a party-less political system that gave the king extensive powers. He dismissed the elected government and banned political parties, establishing direct royal rule. He modernized Nepal's infrastructure and promoted development projects. He also played a role in Nepal's foreign policy, maintaining neutrality between India and China. He died of a heart attack during a hunting trip in Chitlang.

name: Birendra Bir Bikram Shah
title: Tenth King of Nepal
info: Birendra Bir Bikram Shah became king at the age of 27 following his father's death. His reign saw the People's Movement (Jana Andolan) of 1990, which led to the end of the Panchayat system and the establishment of constitutional monarchy. He accepted multiparty democracy and a new constitution in 1990. He was known for his proposals for Nepal as a 'Zone of Peace' and his efforts to maintain good relations with both India and China. He, along with most of his family, was killed in the Narayanhiti Palace massacre on June 1, 2001.

name: Dipendra Bir Bikram Shah
title: Eleventh King of Nepal
info: Dipendra Bir Bikram Shah was proclaimed king while in a coma after the Narayanhiti Palace massacre. According to the official investigation, he was responsible for killing his father King Birendra and other family members on June 1, 2001, before shooting himself. He was declared king while unconscious and died three days later in hospital. His reign of 3 days was the shortest in Nepal's history. The circumstances of the massacre remain controversial, with some questioning the official version of events.

name: Gyanendra Bir Bikram Shah
title: Twelfth and Last King of Nepal
info: Gyanendra Bir Bikram Shah became king for the second time following the death of his nephew Dipendra. He had briefly been king in 1950 as a child when his grandfather Tribhuvan fled to India. His second reign was marked by political instability and the Maoist insurgency. In 2005, he dismissed the government and assumed direct rule, which led to widespread protests. The People's Movement II (Jana Andolan II) in 2006 forced him to restore parliament. In 2008, the monarchy was abolished by the Constituent Assembly, and Nepal became a federal republic. He was the last king of Nepal.
